prior_works.title: A Watermark for Large Language Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the greenlist/redlist, windowed biasing scheme and z-statistic detection that define the core scrubbing–spoofing trade-off SEEK explicitly expands by redesigning token support within each window.

prior_works.title: SWEET: Soft Watermarks for Language Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that distributing watermark signal across many candidate tokens improves robustness to edits, motivating SEEK’s idea of multiple equivalent tokens per window to create redundancy without sacrificing detectability.

prior_works.title: SemStamp: A Semantic Watermark for Large Language Models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Targeted scrubbing (e.g., paraphrasing) via semantics-preserving redundancy, informing SEEK’s focus on resilience to content-preserving edits while keeping the detector keyed and statistical.

prior_works.title: Attacking LLM Watermarks via Reverse Engineering and Likelihood Shaping
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that small-window, statistics-based watermarks can be spoofed by reconstructing token partitions, motivating SEEK’s sub-vocabulary decomposition that preserves spoofing resistance despite added redundancy.

prior_works.title: Optimal Probabilistic Fingerprinting Codes
prior_works.role: Redundancy and code design against deletion/collusion
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the coding-theoretic instinct that multiple valid symbols (redundant code support) can yield robustness to deletions, inspiring SEEK’s equivalent texture keys as a within-window redundancy mechanism.

prior_works.title: Collusion-Secure Fingerprinting for Digital Data
prior_works.role: Foundations of robust, keyed marking under adversaries
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced principles for keyed, collusion-resistant marks that influenced SEEK’s emphasis on maintaining high key entropy and spoofing resistance while adding redundancy.

prior_works.title: WaterBench: Benchmarking LLM Watermarking under Paraphrasing and Spoofing
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Documented the empirical Pareto frontier between scrubbing and spoofing robustness, against which SEEK positions its Pareto improvement via equivalent token supports per window.

synthesis_narrative:
SEEK builds directly on the canonical greenlist/redlist watermark of Kirchenbauer et al., where a keyed partition of the vocabulary within sliding windows yields a z-statistic for detection. That framework exposes a structural trade-off: smaller windows better survive scrubbing (e.g., paraphrasing and token deletions) but are easier to reverse-engineer, enabling low-cost spoofing. Two contemporaneous strands informed SEEK’s solution. First, soft and semantic watermarks such as SWEET and SemStamp demonstrated that distributing signal across many candidate tokens or semantics-preserving alternatives enhances edit resilience—an idea SEEK generalizes by introducing equivalent texture keys: multiple tokens inside each window that independently contribute to the same detection statistic. Second, recent spoofing work (e.g., reverse engineering and likelihood shaping attacks) showed that naively increasing redundancy or shrinking windows can leak the keyed partition, enabling counterfeit watermarked text. SEEK counters this by decomposing the vocabulary into keyed sub-vocabularies that preserve high entropy per window, hindering inversion while keeping multiple equivalent supports.
Coding-theoretic insights from Tardos codes and Boneh–Shaw fingerprinting underlie SEEK’s redundancy design: robustness to deletions and tampering comes from spreading evidence across independently valid symbols, while secrecy hinges on a strong key and randomized assignment. Evaluations like WaterBench framed the Pareto frontier between scrubbing and spoofing; SEEK’s sub-vocabulary equivalent keys expand that frontier, achieving higher scrubbing resilience without compromising spoofing robustness.
